awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Design and Construction of a Synthetic Fungus-Bacterium Consortium for Efficient Cellulosic Biofuel Production
awd_abstract_narration:
PI:  Xiaoxia Lin
Proposal Number: 1055227

Intellectual Merit

Consolidated bioprocessing (CBP)seeks to combine several distinct biological functions for production of biologically-derived products into one system in order to reduce process complexity.  When CBP is applied to lignocellulosic biomass conversion to biofuels, cellulase production, cellulose hydrolysis, and hexose/pentose sugar fermentation are consolidated into a single bioreactor.  The overall goal of the proposed research is to engineer a synthetic fungus-bacterium consortium for production of isobutanol, an advanced biofuel, from renewable lignocellulosic feedstocks.    The consortium design is inspired by the ubiquitous synergistic microbial communities found in Nature.   The overall strategy is to construct and optimize a microbial consortium consisting of a cellulose-degrading fungus and biofuel-producing bacteria for cellulosic biofuel production.  Specifically, the proposed research plan will 1) Develop specialized bacterium and fungus strains suitable for consortium operation; 2) Devise and implement genetic circuits for consortium regulation; and 3) Enhance isobutanol tolerance of consortium members.  The proposed research has the potential to generate new microbial engineering strategies, most notably the creation of robust synthetic consortia and genome engineering for phenotypic improvement.   These engineered microbial consortia can be valuable for a broad range of applications.  The proposed research is also designed to advance basic understanding of microbial metabolism and physiology with specific emphasis on alcohol toxicity.

Broader Impacts

The proposed education and outreach plan focuses on undergraduate students in engineering and female students from the K-12 to graduate level.   A new cross- disciplinary undergraduate course in synthetic biology for will be developed, and will feature capstone activity for team-based sustainable design in the context of the international Genetically Engineered Machine (iGEM) competition.   Outreach activities are designed to broaden the participation of women in science and engineering disciplines, and will be coordinated through the WISE (Women in Science and Engineering) program at the undergraduate and graduate levels, and through K-12 summer camp programs at the University of Michigan.

por.por_cntn:
In this project funded by the NSF CAREER program, we have developed an innovative and transformative technology, based on synthetic microbial consortia, for converting lignocellulosic biomass to advanced biofuels in a highly efficient manner. Lignocellulose, such as corn stover and wood chips, is an abundant and inexpensive feedstock for renewable and sustainable production of fuels and chemicals. Due to its complex structure, this bio-resource is highly recalcitrant to decomposition, which represents a major barrier for its widespread utilization. To address this challenge, we draw on inspirations from metabolically versatile and robust microbial communities in nature and exploit an alternative approach for microbial engineering and biochemical production - design and construction of synthetic microbial consortia consisting of different specialists to accomplish a complicated task. Specifically, we have designed, constructed and optimized a synthetic microbial consortium integrating cellulolytic fungus T. reesei and genetically engineered E. coli. This system is capable of cellulase production, enzymatic hydrolysis, hexose and pentose fermentation all in one bioreactor. Such an innovation enables the consolidated bioprocessing (CBP) scheme, which could substantially reduce both the capital and operational costs of a biorefinery for large-scale production of lignocellulosic biofuels. Our proof-of-concept work demonstrated conversion of linocellulosic biomass to isobutanol, a promising “drop-in” biofuel that is compatible with the current transportation infrastructure. More details of this work can be found at:

http://www.ns.umich.edu/new/multimedia/videos/21643-microbial-team-turns-corn-stalks-and-leaves-into-better-biofuel

 

The technology described above is highly modular. Its extensions and variations (e.g. with the biofuel-producing bacteria substituted by other microorganisms for different target molecules) can be readily applied to the production of other fuels or chemicals from renewable lignocellulosic biomass. Additionally, we have developed new genome evolution and engineering approaches for elucidating and improving microbial tolerance to toxic chemicals, in particular alcohols.
